review:
Heroes of Hellas 3 is a match-3 game. 
The game is part of a series of four games (so far) that the developers have released.
I have played and completed all parts. Part 3 was the easiest. All fours games are different but great.
In contrast to the other three parts, Heroes of Hellas 3 unfortunately has no Steam achievements. That's a bit of a shame.

As for match-3 games, the Hellas series are the best match-3 games I have played. A true work of love. Very relaxing and at the same time highly addictive, and simply lovely and entertaining.

Highly recommend!

i really liked Heroes of Hellas 3 ( i have not played the other games of this series) but it slightly overstayed its welcome in my opinion. 

The levels start of fine at first, they have a good bit variety and more and more extra mechanics are added over time. Eventually, the levels take more and more time tho (in the end it took me almost 10 minutes for one level), the level structure changes over and over so that you have to pretty much start over clearing the "map" multiple times. Especially the last 13 story levelsreally overdid it in that regard. Other than that i absolutely enjoyed my time with this game and can recommend it to anyone who is looking for a relaxing game to spend some time on. :D

review:
[i]Heroes of Hellas 3: Athens[/i] is a very good match-3 game with engaging gameplay and with enough variation in its many levels to feel like playing 'just one more level' before calling it a night.


[h1]Story[/h1]

Athens is in ruins and it's up to you to rebuild the city. You'll need coin for that, which you'll earn by completing match-3 levels. While rebuilding the city, some gods will look  favourably upon you and offer help, whereas other gods will unleash disastrous events on the city you're trying to rebuild. Discover who's behind all this and how you need to defeat that god. Fortunately you'll be able to count on a helping hand by some of the other gods.


[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

There are several types of gameplay for creating a chain of tiles in match-3 games. In [i]Heroes of Hellas 3: Athens[/i], you click and drag your mouse pointer over a number of adjacent tiles that can be combined. Releasing the mouse button will execute your move. 

By executing a move the tiles you selected disappear and all the 'strong tiles' adjacent to your selected tiles get damaged. By strong tiles I mean reinforced stone tiles, frozen tiles, and tiles protected by one or two ropes or chains. 

Dragging the mouse pointer across at least three tiles of the same color is a classic match. But a valid selection of tiles in [i]Heroes of Hellas 3: Athens[/i] may also include coins, bombs and lightning circles. These act like wild cards to make a valid selection of tiles. So two bombs and one orange tile are a valid match-3 in this game. 

The coins you collect are meant to pay for building structures in the town of Athens.

Lightning circles make lightning explode from that tile in various directions. Lightning destroys all basic tiles and coins, and keeps going until it hits the edge of the game board or until it hits and damages a strong tile.

Bombs cause an area-of-effect explosion, destroying simple tiles and coins, and damaging strong tiles. Stronger bombs mean stronger explosions. 

As the story progresses and as you continue building structures in Athens, a number of gods will help you with your efforts. Every god has a different way to help you. Think of things like destroying tiles, rearranging tiles, turning tiles into coins, and more.

Also, every god has its very own type of tile. By collecting the tiles that are related to a particular god, you charge the power of that god. When the god's skill charge reaches a certain limit, you can use that power. Patience to fill the god's power to its full potential before unleashing it is often most rewarding but it depends on the situation.

In every level of the game you get three gods standing by to help you. The three types of tiles connected with those three gods will be among the tiles on the playfield. Tiles related to other gods never turn up in that level. 

When starting a new game, you have to choose between 'relaxed mode' and 'timed mode'. As you suspect, timed mode means you have a ticking clock on your screen and you have to finish the level before the clock runs out. In relaxed mode you have all the time in the world.


[h1]Graphics and sound[/h1]

Graphics are as nice as you can expect from a match-3 game. Sound effects are serviceable enough.

A special shoutout for the music in this game. Sure, the few alternating tunes get repetitive but a couple of them really managed to stick with me and were playing joyfully in my mind after a gaming session.


[h1]On Steam's extra features[/h1]

[i]Heroes of Hellas 3: Athens[/i] has 6 Steam Trading Cards. You'll get 3 while running the game.

The game has no Steam Achievements but it does have built-in achievements. All of them have three levels (stars). Most of them are easy to max out simply by playing the game, but at least one achievement isn't easy to acquire because it requires completing levels before half of the time runs out, meaning you can't get this achievement in relaxed mode.

review:
It all works. Nothing exciting, and their grasp of ancient Greece is hilariously bad, but it is a fun little time waster. 
The HOG games are the weakest point so far, not very good, but the match-3 is okay. 
It is the match three where you find chains, not move gems or candy, guessing that makes a difference for some people. 
There is a rebuild-the-city thing going on, but it isn't game play, you don't really get to pick anything but the color.
Got it on sale, and easy thumbs up at the price I paid, about half a buck.
ADDENDUM: About fifteen hours, start to finish on the story mode on relaxed. There are additional bonus levels where you get to build a palace, and it has been fun enough that I will give it a look see. 
ADDENDUM: 18.5 hours start to finish, including the bonus levels. Not too shabby. The puzzle levels were perfect for me, who can get frustrated easily, a bit of thought required, but never too hard. 
Two thumbs up, had great fun.
Posted my final palace to screen prints. Not really a spoiler as each step of the way you get two choices.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044983093', 'num_games_owned': 2355, 'num_reviews': 204, 'playtime_forever': 3676, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3676, 'last_played': 1591289128}
review:
Match-three gameplay, of the drag-a-line kind rather than the swapping kind. As a match-three game, it's excellent. Different colours charge up special moves, such as shuffling the board, or breaking frozen tiles, etc. Often you need to plan ahead and think about your chains will affect the distribution of the board, in order to eventually target a certain tile.

The main objective of the game is city-building, but that aspect is shallow and too linear. I wish it was more fleshed out, and affected the gameplay somehow. I thought the buildings I was unlocking would give me special powers in the tile-matching parts, but it was just window dressing. Wasted potential there, but it wasn't annoying.
One thing I was impressed with was that your god's-eye view of the city allowed you to see dozens of citizens milling around, performing various tasks, and each one of them was named and can be clicked on to read their thoughts.

Occasionally there are object-hunting minigames, which unlock the special moves I mentioned above. This was the only part of the game that I actually disliked. I am very into hidden-object games, and there's a right way and a wrong way to do them; and it was all wrong here. The way the objects are hidden is obnoxious, forcing you to tediously hover over the entire screen to see the mouse cursor highlights.

But most of the time, you'll be tile-matching, and it's really good. It's got depth, with many mechanics are that introduced bit by bit. I mean, I spent 60 hours on it, and that was just the campaign. There's a bunch of challenge levels afterwards.

review:
Tags: Casual - Match3
Additional Tags: Delete Local Content & Remove from LIbrary

TLDR: Match3 citybuilding hybrid formula from 7 Wonders, retweaked for tablets, then ported back to PC. Play the original concept instead.

This is hexgrid draw-a-line with collectibles sprinkled in that you gotta slide all the way to the bottom of the board or collect by breaking background by matching tiles on top. You spend ressources to rebuild a small scale greek city presented like an old Caesar game. God game aspect reminds vaguely of Hexus and 7 Wonders series. Engine felt fairly stable. Color palette was nice and relaxing enough to the eye. Assets were not too atrociously low res for it to be distracting. No proper resolutions support which is still unfortunate.

Overall I would rather just stick to the original formula. The draw-a-line retweaks are not a value added when using a mice and the original experience has better flow has a sit down pc entertainment experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971047607', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 1325, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1325, 'last_played': 1466263979}
review:
I picked this game up in a bundle and wasn't expecting much. I was wrong.
80% Puzzle Game / 15% Hidden Object Game / 5% City Builder
Heroes of Hellas 3 is a mix of 3 different genres. Initially a "Match 3" puzzle game, it's a game that keeps on giving. Puzzle mechanics lead to city building, which is very basic, and is simply there to provide a goal. Most puzzle games try to keep your interest with score's or stars, but Heroes keeps you playing because you want to rebuild Athens. Then just when you start to figure out what the game is, it hits you with HO scenes and then again with resources being hidden within the main city screen as well. It's addictive, and not short, the levels just keep coming, and then when you eventually beat the game, it unlocks bonus content that's as good as anything in the game with additional puzzles you need to solve in limited moves, real brain teasers, and the ability to customise your own palace!
Overall, the game is well presented, music, graphics and sound effects are above average, all set in an ancient Greece.
It's incredibly casual, incredibly cheap considering the amount of content, but incredibly addictive and relaxing. A hidden gem.

review:
This game was super addictive and challenging. It's not enough to match shapes with each other, you have to do legitimate problem solving. Solving a puzzle is fun, and you feel a real sense of accomplishment once you reach the next stage. 

Just as importantly, it works on low end hardware. I had no problem running this on my HP Stream which runs on a Celeron processor on 2GB of RAM. And when I output this on a TV through HDMI, it had no problem with the higher resolution, working like a charm. Though this game doesn't officially support it, I found the Steam Controller much more satisfying to use than my laptop trackpad.

The hidden object of the game wasn't as satisfying as the puzzling. Thankfully, there's much much more puzzling than hidden object. 

Finally, this is a great game to play with a toddler. My 2-year-old daughter loved watch the shapes match with each other, along with the explosions. She was thoroughly entertained. 

Highly recommended!

review:
Heroes of Hellas 3 is primarily a tile-matching game on a hex grid, with a chain-drawing mechanic.  It's not wildly innovative, but it's solid, well-made casual fun for those who like the match-3 style, but want something a little bit differenct from the standard match-3 gameplay.

The game is padded out with a few scenes of city-building and hidden objects.  These scenes are fluff, add nothing, and should be ignored, but they can usually be dispensed with quickly, so they don't detract too much.  the writing (in English at least) is somewhat clumsy, but you aren't really playing this for the story; you're playing for the actual tile-matching levels, and those are quite satisfying, if not particularly challenging.

review: I both liked and despised this game.  The basic gameplay (make trails of 3+ matching tokens to clear them) is entertaining and the minigames like the city building and hidden object screens, while slight, are nice diversions.  But when the level I'm working on completely reconfigures itself, undoing all the work I've done, for the FOURTH time, I got tired of it.  And that was around Sequence 4, of 8.  And then there are the obnoxious design choices like the coins - which you collect to make buildings. Fine and good, except some of the level types that include coins don't actually get counted. There are reasons, but not good enough to justify it.  When levels in a casual game can take 10-15 minutes to complete, and working to get the coins is wasted effort, it makes the game too frustrating to recommend. Casual players may like it for a while, but if you're like me and want to get to the end, you'll be tearing your hair out in frustration.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024972696', 'num_games_owned': 319, 'num_reviews': 262, 'playtime_forever': 1799, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1799, 'last_played': 1435808902}
review:
If you like casual Match 3 (M3) games, then "Heroes of Hellas 3: Athens" is for you.  The games, themselves, are just fine.  The story wrapper they use to try to link the games into some more meaningful whole (restoring Athens and then building a palace) could be done away with entirely.  But, that doesn't detract from the actual gameplay.  Also, just for completeness, you should know that the M3s have Fractured Object Games (FROGs) and Move Limited Match 3 (MLM3) games interspersed throughout them.  I'm not a fan of FROGs, but they're only about one every "level" of the main game (there are 8 levels of 13 games (I believe)).  The MLM3s are half of the "bonus" "Build your Palace" portion.

The game does have some issues, though.  First, it's an old game and doesn't limit its frame rate.  When I first started it, I noticed my fans ramping up on my graphics card.  When I checked the frame rate, it was over a thousand.  So, I had to install RivaTuner and set up a frame rate limit (60 fps) for the game.  Second, the story around the actual games is really just tacked on and useless.  I'd have been happier with a grid showing games available and games done just like they did in the "bonus" portion where you build your palace.  And, finally, the palace you build in that "bonus" portion is a mess:  it's ugly, badly designed, and badly drawn.  But, again, it's just a wrapper around the actual games.

But, overall, I got about 30 hours of good play (24 hours in the main game, 6 hours in the "bonus" game) out of this $3.99 (which I got in a bundle, so the cost was utterly trivial).  If you like M3s, then I recommend this game.  Good value for the money.

review:
A chain-match match-3 game, with a Greek mythology theme, a minimal city management aspect built in, and the occasional hidden object or other stage thrown in for variety. I actually really enjoyed this for a few reasons, one being that the board is a hex-grid, and not the standard square, leading to more abilities to match, as well as the fact that it also has puzzle-like maps where the goal is to figure out how to get some objects off the board with abilities.

Quite good! Would highly recommend if you like casual titles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126326583', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 154, 'last_played': 1430234364}
review:
A light-hearted Match 3 builder game with Greek Mythology elements. You play The Builder who saves Athens from volcanoes and others that try to ruin it. 

Pros:
+Very beautiful texture, artwork, and soundtrack. 
+You get Both timed and nontimed mode. This is nice because I can up or down the difficulty on my choosing. It gives the player a sense of control.
+The gameplay is pretty fun and the different gods having a powerup(to help clear the board) is a nice bonus. 
+Smooth FPS
+It changes the gameplay occasionally to keep it from being monotonous. 

Cons: 
- My only complaint about this game was the 3.99 price. I would've gladly handed over 5 bucks because the designers deserve it. 

Overall:
A well polished game that I can easily pick up and drop. There's no rush and nothing that causes me stress. I would buy this if you into the Match 3 Realm. :)

review:
Just a quick review for those wondering if they should get it while it's on sale.

So far I am happy with my purchase and recommend it for fans of Match 3 games.  This one kinda reminds me of 4 Elements because you match by clicking, holding down the mouse button, and dragging it through all the gems of the same color that are by each other.  There are occasional hidden object puzzles where you have to find little pieces of an object that are scattered throughout a scene.  

There is also some town building.  You get gold after each match 3 level and use it to buy buildings.  There is a choice of 3 different types of buildings with increasing cost.  I don't know what that's all about yet.  So far I've just been choosing the cheapest buildings.  For instance, first you build a house and they give you 3 options of housing.  The more expensive ones have more decoration.  I don't know if they do anything else.

And of course there are power ups in the match 3 levels.  There's a lightning icon that will destroy all the gems and things in a line, sometimes a straight line and sometimes diagonal.  There's rope and stone blocks that need to be destroyed before more gems can fall.  There's a wing icon that reveals hidden parts of the board.  Gems and treasure chests that give you more gold!

I will update as I play more.
